conclusion: To determine the change in magnetic flux, calculate initial and final magnetic fluxes and find their difference.
The initial position of the coil is such that the plane of the coil is perpendicular to the magnetic field direction (positive x-axis).
The initial magnetic flux Φi is given by Φi = B · A · cos(θi).
The initial magnetic flux is Φi = 0.1 T × 0.4 m² × 1 = 0.04 Wb.
The coil rotates 60° downward around the z-axis.
The final angle θf between the magnetic field and the normal to the coil's plane is 60°.
The final magnetic flux Φf is given by Φf = B · A · cos(θf).
Since cos(60°) = 0.5, the final magnetic flux is Φf = 0.1 T × 0.4 m² × 0.5 = 0.02 Wb.
The change in magnetic flux ΔΦ is the difference between the final and initial magnetic fluxes: ΔΦ = Φf - Φi.
Substituting the values, ΔΦ = 0.02 Wb - 0.04 Wb = -0.02 Wb.
The change in the magnetic flux passing through the coil is -0.02 Wb.
